channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Northland floods leave homes uninhabitable, farms under water
item.description: As the flood waters recede in Northland the full extent of the damage from the weekend's deluge is becoming clear.

item.title: The Warehouse employees to be told of job losses
item.description: The Warehouse employees will learn their fate this morning, as the company plans to axe about 1000 jobs.

item.title: Campaign launches to sustain interest in New Zealand amid pandemic
item.description: A new multi-agency campaign is being launched to promote New Zealand overseas amid border closures and the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Science fiction and fantasy fosters our future - researcher
item.description: Sci-fi and fantasy may help young people cope, especially with the stress and anxiety of living through Covid-19, a US researcher says.

item.title: Disabled jobseeker told she would only get job 'if someone feels bad'
item.description: A woman living with cerebral palsy has been told by a recruitment agency she would only find work if a business took pity on her.

item.title: Will we all get Covid-19 eventually?
item.description: Mutations of the Covid-19 coronavirus could allow it to spread more easily between people, but there is also some evidence one mutation has slightly reduced its force, a professor in molecular immunology says.

item.title: Full extent of Northland floods still not clear: Henare
item.description: More rain this afternoon in Northland may exacerbate surface flooding and slips throughout the region after heavy rain this weekend.

item.title: Truck and three cars in serious crash near Hunterville
item.description: A serious crash between a truck and three cars has closed State Highway 1 near Hunterville in the central North Island.

item.title: Farmers face big clean up after Northland floods
item.description: River and stream levels in the region are dropping, but many low-lying paddocks remain inundated with floodwater.

item.title: Three new cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today
item.description: There have been three new cases of Covid-19 reported in managed isolation in New Zealand today, the Health Ministry has confirmed.

item.title: DOC fed up with Pureora Forest vandalism thwarting volunteer efforts
item.description: The Department of Conservation wants the public to name and shame vandals after Pureora Forest shelter was targeted again, despite recently being fixed by volunteers.

item.title: Waikato Regional Council reinstates some catchment committees
item.description: The Waikato Regional Council is bringing back some of the 12 catchment committees it dis-established eight months ago.

item.title: Universities want detail on student quarantine requirements
item.description: Universities are calling for more details from the government so they can develop a quarantine model for foreign students.

item.title: More rain forecast for Northland as clean-up continues
item.description: The worst of the rough weather that has pounded Northland over the past two days has eased, but MetService says there is still a risk of more rain today.

item.title: Conservationists sceptical about new Waihi open pit mine plan
item.description: Conservationists say a new open pit mine proposed for Waihi and a large expansion of gold mining operations are not a wise choice for New Zealand communities.

item.title: Universal Family Benefit part of NZ First plan
item.description: New Zealand First has announced a policy to bring in a universal family benefit, allowing families to put down a deposit on a first home.

item.title: National's $31b transport plan 'pricey but worth it' - Bishop
item.description: National's massive $31 billion plan to improve infrastructure in the upper half of the North Island is expensive but will "move the dial on congestion", says Infrastructure and Transport spokesperson Chris Bishop.

item.title: Police acknowledge claim against racial bias was false
item.description: Police figures have debunked claims made by the former police commissioner that there is no racial bias when it comes to deciding whether a suspect should be charged.
